messages: 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:20): So, suppose I'm a web developer and give users the ability to create images somehow.  Suppose the user provides no alt text, for whatever reason.  Should I put no alt attribute, or empty alt text, or something else?  Is there any guidance about this?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:21): That's one of the controversial areas
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:21): Yeah, I figured.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:22): It seems to me that logically, you'd want to either have no alt attribute or a magic value.  Having alt="" or the filename or whatever strikes me as bad from everyone's perspective.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:23): But it also strikes me that if you allow this, then suddenly zillions of sites will have to switch from alt="" to your magic value and everyone will be forced to admit that few sites have ever used decent alt text.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:23): As opposed to calling required alt text a success, as a Mozilla developer recently did on public-html.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:23): You just use missing alt as your magic value
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:23): Yes, that seems to make the most sense.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:23): Well, the controversy isn't just the syntax, but also whether it should be conforming or not
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:23): Not to the Experts
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:24): But then you get people complaining that your app isn't conforming, unless missing alt text is conforming.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:24): unless they changed their minds
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:24): So you're pressured into missing alt text.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:24): That's how it ends up, yes
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:24): I mean, you're pressured into adding empty or useless alt text.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:24): If missing alt is the solution, and missing alt is nonconforming, you get bogus alt
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:25): If magic value is the solution, you get bogus magic value
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:25): What I'd like is some guidance that actually tells me what the best course of action is for screen readers.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:25): Current or future or science-fiction screen readers?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:25): If missing alt is the solution, and missing alt is conforming, you get "but that's not machine checkable"
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:25): Surely screen readers need to know the difference between "don't know what the alt should be" and "alt should be empty, this is decorative".
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:25): Current or near future.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:25): Screen readers want missing alt
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:25): They have to handle those anyway
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:26): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, do they want it more than filler like the filename?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:26): I assume they could fill in the filename themselves.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:26): Or other useful info.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:26): Decorative is easy, that's just alt=""
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:26): I'm sure you can find enough screen readers to justify either case
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:26): Because apparently we have to consider every version of every product ever released
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:27): (JAWS is currently version 11, but version 4 is brought up in discussions...)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:27): And every user's configuration of said products
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:30): Maybe nobody upgrades JAWS because of how ludicrously expensive it is?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:31): That's the common argument
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:32): A blind person once told me Mac's built-in screen reader is the best.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:33): Other blind people may say very different things
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:34): is unaware of objective comparisons between the various products
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:34): guesses people learn to use one and then want to stick with it for a long time, because it's so hard to learn another even if it's supposedly better
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:34): What he said completely met my expectations of the different platforms, though, so I'm inclined to believe him.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:35): He said on Windows, the software is lousy, made by third parties, and unreasonably expensive.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:35): On Linux, it's still lousy, but at least it's free.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:35): On Mac, it comes with the OS and is excellent.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:35): I'd expect Apple to make a good screen reader.  It's the sort of thing they do well.  UI, basically.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:36): Whereas open-source stuff, and random special-purpose Windows apps, tend to have lousy UI.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:38): Looks like JAWS is about $900, but presumably you get significant discounts via employers or other groups
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:38): so maybe JAWS + a cheap Windows PC/laptop is still cheaper than a Mac
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:39): You can surely get a Mac of some kind for $900.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:40): You can, but you can get a Windows one for much less, and the difference may be greater than a discounted JAWS
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:41): Seems like it won't be a huge difference, though
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:41): Why do you assume that you can get a discounted JAWS so easily?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:46): Isn't that the norm?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (19:46): Bulk discounts for organizations

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:46): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Because they talk about multi-user pricing on their site, and because I vaguely remember some mentioning how people often get that kind of thing through an employer rather than buying it personally
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:46): though I could be entirely misremembering and/or wrong
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:46): s/some/someone/
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:46): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, if you have an entire organization of blind people, yes.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (19:47): I assume they can charge so much for JAWS because users can get some kind of subsidy
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:47): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Any reasonably large organisation will probably have enough to make it worthwhile

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:47): On the other hand, maybe blind people do tend to work for companies full of blind people.  I suppose they'd have some trouble at a random employer, even in a carefully-selected field.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:47): wonders about that.

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:48): The first time I ever saw a blind person actually at work was here at Google.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:48): Dude works in one of the nearby buildings.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:49): I can't imagine it's most.

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:49): I just see him at lunch.
